typeDescriptions.style: Code style changes (formatting, whitespace, missing semicolons, etc.) that do not affect code meaning
typeDescriptions.refactor: Code changes that neither fix bugs nor add features (code restructuring, improving readability)
typeDescriptions.chore: Maintenance tasks, dependency updates, build configuration changes
typeDescriptions.build: Build system or external dependencies changes

guidelines: Omit if change affects multiple areas or is too broad

subject.description: what the commit does, not why or how

good: fix(ui): resolve crash on mobile devices

guidelines: Separated from subject by blank line
May use bullet points for multiple changes

rules: Type is required and must be one of the listed types
Scope is optional but recommended when the change is localized
Subject must be imperative mood, present tense, lowercase
Use English for all commit messages
No period at the end of the subject
Body and footer are optional but useful for complex changes
Reference issues in the footer, not the subject
Be descriptive but concise - focus on what changed
contextAwareRules: Analyze the diff to determine the appropriate type and scope
Group related changes - if multiple files change for one feature, use one commit
Be specific - 'fix button alignment' is better than 'fix bug'
Match the branch type - if branch is 'feature/login', commit should be 'feat'
Consider the impact - breaking changes must be marked in the footer
Use technical terms correctly - match the terminology used in the codebase

examples.bugFix: fix(ui): resolve button alignment issue on mobile
examples.refactoring: refactor(api): extract authentication logic into separate module
examples.performance: perf(api): optimize database query for user lookup
examples.test: test(auth): add unit tests for login flow

breakingChange.subject: feat(api): change authentication endpoint structure
breakingChange.body:
BREAKING CHANGE: The /auth/login endpoint now requires email instead of username.
Update all API clients to use the new field name.

checks: Type is one of the allowed types
Subject is in imperative mood, present tense
Subject does not end with a period
Breaking changes are marked in footer if applicable
